reviewText: Though this film is painful to watch--it's never easy to watch hapless people floundering around with no clue how to rectify their situation--it's so amazingly well done in all ways:  the script, the cinematography, the acting--not a weak link in the bunch. Though Daniels and Linney shine, avoiding any form of cliche or attitude, it's really the two younger actors who deserve huge amounts of credit.  Child performers so often seem way too precocious (think Dakota Fanning), but these two young men do an outstanding job of portraying the children of two confused adults and showing how this confusion infects their lives and personalities.  For a stunning, thought-provoking, touching, realistic view of the darker side of family life, give this movie a viewing.If I could, I'd give it 4.5 stars. The only thing that keeps it from being a solid 5 is that it ends rather suddenly.  I'm glad that they didn't aim for any artificial, wrap-up kind of ending--that would have been annoying and it would have destroyed the delicate ambiguity they had established throughout.  Still, when the credits rolled my reaction was "How can they end it there?"  I see what they were aiming for (I think) but I think somehow they could have made the conclusion a little more satisfactory ....

I loved that there was no sanctimonious moralizing about either the parents' or the boys' behavior, overt or otherwise. (I hate to be bludgeoned by a movie...it got my money, it got my undivided attention...what more does it want? I mean, I'll form my own judgments, thank you.)The movie made me sad, but it was funny, too, in a dark and very disturbing way.  Every character was sort of floating around in his/her own painful, self-absorbed, angst-filled bubble, trying to inflict the greatest amount of pain on whomever happened to cross his/her path.  Genius!

You can believe the pain in the children's eyes and though their acts, in fill adolescence and awakening sexuality.  The mother, who could not go on the way it was, is indulging her need for a kind of simple lover, disastrously choosing her son's tennis teacher.  Even worse, the father cannot look into himself, and acts out the bad guy as he dates a woman his older son has a crush on while the son is mistreating a very nice girl his age.  It is all agonisingly sad to watch, and all the introspection that can lead to growing out of it is under the surface in ways that the viewer must interpret it. reviewText: ***1/2Using his own adolescent experiences as his source of inspiration, writer/director Noah Baumbach turns "The Squid and the Whale" into a searing, uncompromising look at the devastating effect divorce has on the various members of a family unit.Jeff Daniels portrays the effete Bernard Berkman, a once-successful novelist who is now an English professor at a local college in Brooklyn.  A name-dropping elitist whose every sentence drips with pretentious commentary and barely disguised contempt for the unwashed masses, Berkman clearly sees himself as the last bastion in a war against all the no-nothing "Philistines" who have come to ravage and ruin the culture.  It is this very attitude that Berkman seems to have inculcated into his oldest son, Walt (Jesse Eisenberg), who spends most of his time idolizing his dad, adopting his tastes in art, literature and even women, and mimicking his comments.  Laura Linney plays Bernard's wife, Joan, whose career as a writer is beginning to bloom just as Bernard's has begun to fade.  Much of the tension between the husband and wife comes from Bernard's inability to accept this turn of events.  The fourth member of the family is the younger son, Frank (Owen Kline), who is far more devoted to his mother than to his father and who begins to act out against the divorce in very bizarre and very seriously disturbed ways. The film does a fine job showing the emotional toll divorce takes on children as they often become helpless pawns in the power struggles waged by the two "combatants."Baumbach has kept his film simple and unadorned, rarely going for the big or grand gesture but, instead, letting the drama act itself out in small moments that are both believable and telling.  The performances by the four leads are superb down to the smallest detail, and they receive fine support from Halley Feiffer, Anna Paquin and William Baldwin in lesser but still crucial roles."The Squid and the Whale" barely runs 80 minutes, and although it could possibly use a bit more development of character and theme, the movie still manages to pack a great deal of insight and observation into that short time period, making it one of the most interesting movies about family relationships that we've come across in quite some time.

reviewText: "The Squid and the Whale" tells the story of a family being torn apart by its apparent intellect.  Bernard and Joan have been married long enough to tire of each other completely.  Joan (Laura Linney) has been a burgeoning author for years, but is only now finding enough success to escape her husband's shadow.  Bernard (the latest in a long line of horrible husbands played by Jeff Daniels) was once a great writer, but hasn't had a hit in years.  Now he molders teaching while his wife's career and motherhood eclipses his blocked fame and parental instincts.  We learn quickly that for his wisdom, Bernard is a louse.  After splitting with Joan, Bernard takes up residence in a crumbling Brooklyn brownstone, sharing his new home with Lilly (Anna Paquin), one of his students.While having strong opinions of the two parents, "Whale" doesn't really preach against them.  Rather, the story is more concerned with the effects on the ending of this marriage on their two sons - teenage Walt and his younger brother Frank.  Being older, Walt has very adult tastes which his father proves ready both to satisfy and (given his intellect) to rationalize.  The younger Frank proves unreceptive to his father, so Bernard pretty much ignores him.  Alienated, Frank turns to sexual and alcoholic experimentation.  Moving in with Bernard, and despite the older man's obvious decline, Walt models himself on his father, arming himself with the trappings of an intellect.  (The script ensures that he will fail - in a talent show, he performs Pink Floyd's "Hey You", claiming to have written the song; he takes to using the word "Kafkaesque" until accidentally applying it to a story about Kafka; and he utterly muffs things up with Lilly; ultimately, both of Bernard and Joan's sons will draw their parents into embarrassing confrontations at school.)"Whale" is evocatively made, but it still seems pointless.  It's sort of like a filmed version of one of those stories you see every week in "The New Yorker" - academic backgrounds of the characters, references to arty movies, scenes in which characters who make critical decisions after a period of self-reflection, plots in which very little actually happens - stories which boil down to elaborate character sketches bereft of plot.  Clearly we can't sympathize with Bernard, and given the harm he's wreaking on his sons, he becomes downright hateful.  Even if Walt can't recognize the harm that his father has wrought on their family, there's no way the boy could miss the decline that he's suffered.  It's just too difficult to understand how even the older boy could take Bernard's side.

reviewText: Parents screw kids up. Maybe a lot, maybe a little, and in every way imaginable, but it happens, just as surely as parents enrich and instruct their sons and daughters. Noah Baumbach's fictional memoir, "The Squid and The Whale," knows that, and treats its characters- based on his family - with love, yes, but scrutiny, too. It does not declare what parents should be, but it has strong convictions about what they shouldn't:  It is a brilliant, vicious, magnetic, articulate picture about two brilliant, vicious, magnetic, articulate divorcees who inflict sublime pain on the two sons they share with a selfish kind of honesty better suited for the leather couch."Mom, stop. I don't want to hear that from you," says Walt (Jesse Eisenberg) to his mother Joan (Laura Linney) as she describes some long-ago affair in the back of a storeroom."I know," Joan says. " I talk like that sometimes." She doesn't mean she's going to stop.Joan is a writer just beginning to find her voice with pieces in The New Yorker. Ex-husband Bernard (Jeff Daniels) is a novelist, although by 1986, when the story opens, his literary star has dimmed; manuscripts are wait-listed as he teaches creative writing. The screenplay quietly suggests the divorce is tied to the shifting fortunes in Bernard and Joan's careers; certainly 16-year-old Walt believes it, and blames his mother for her wilting loyalty. But Bernard is a competitive, jealous ass - the word was invented for such a man - obsessed intellectual mannerisms and poet-warrior masculinty. He takes a house on the other side of Central Park - the "filet of the neighborhood," he says - and the parents share Walt and 11-year-old Frank (Owen Kline), who prefers Joan.Baumbach has a sad soul - he presents Frank as a kind boy quickly losing his innocence amidst two absent parents - and a wonderful ear. Surely his father, writer John Baumbach, is a partial inspiration for Bernard, but he populates "The Squid and The Whale" with smaller, distinct characters, includng Ivan (William Baldwin), the breezy tennis pro who moves in with Joan, and Lili (Anna Paquin), one of those foolish graduate girls trying on the vixen personality for a couple years. She and Walt both tail around Bernard waiting for the verbal scraps he mindlessly passes as wisdom. Both discover divorce makes pitiful men faster than it produces such women.Bill Murray and Kevin Kline would have made good Bernards, and Jeff Bridges basically played the role in "The Door In The loor" -  but Daniels is the fit. Burly, offhandedly musing in his lilting voice, Bernard's really a bit stupid, and Daniels' performance captures talent trapped in accolades past. His speech and manners points to a verbose, muscular writing that lost steam in the 1980s to the "alternative voices" literary movement of the sick, the abused, and the minority - the kind of culture that produced James Frey's multiple lies in "A Million Little Pieces." As he did with Hap in "Terms of Endearment," Daniels carves out sympathy for the diminished Bernard. And Linney, in an equally skilled performance, diminishes our sympathy for Joan, who indulges her awakening at the expense of her children. She is a shadow of the mother she once was, and maybe knows it. Eisenberg and Kline deliver Baumbach's lines like they know they're funny, although Eisenberg played a similiar role in Dylan Kidd's excellent "Rodger Dodger." The four are fine independently, clever coupled together and excellent when in a quartet.Not all of these niche films with witty, urbane screenplays and and eccentricity work. Baumbach wrote and directed a few clunkers, in fact with "Mr. Jealousy" and "Highball." But here he has the cast, the back-of-his-hand knowledge and an aim beyond the ennui and insecurity of intelligence in America. He's directed a seriously funny picture, one of the best from last year.
summary: Perfectly walks the tightrope between wit and poignancy.

reviewText: "The Squid and the Whale" is a difficult movie to review.  Noah Baumbach wrote and directed this independent movie (and it screams "I'm independent!"), which he allegedly based on his own family experience.  If that is true, Baumbach needs a hug and his parents need a sock in the mouth.This is a difficult movie to review because I think it was an excellent movie - particularly the acting - and yet the movie left me frustrated and miserable.  I was never bored, I was always intrigued, and yet I hated almost the entire viewing experience.The overview of the movie is simple, as it really has no classic three-act plot.  Bernard and Joan Berkman (Jeff Daniels and Laura Linney) are married with two boys, a teenager named Walt (Jesse Eisenberg) and a foul-mouthed ten-year old named Frank (Owen Kline).  The Berkman's marriage is either falling apart or has done so - an early scene of a family tennis match sees Joan peppered by shots from Bernard and Walt.In a traditional comedy, these tennis shots at Mom would have been cleverly done with a funny soundtrack, maybe with a ball nailing Mom in the head for effect.  In this movie, the shots at Mom are fueled by rage and the camera captures that rage dispassionately.  To say that a tone is set is putting it mildly.The movie is set in Brooklyn in the 1980s.  The Berkmans are like Brooklyn, close enough to the greatness of Manhattan to feel self-important, but not quite there.  Bernard sees himself as a great novelist, having written one well-received book.  This entitles him to belittle "A Tale of Two Cities" as "minor Dickens," and generally treat everyone as being there for his convenience.  This, despite the fact that he lost his agent and nobody is interested in his latest book.  Joan is also a lit PhD and has a book deal.  This entitles her to tell her children, "I need some nights away from you guys, okay!"The tagline for this movie is, "Joint custody blows."  It sure does for the Berkmans.  The parents split up, and Bernard moves to an "elegant" house in an "elegant" neighborhood several blocks away.  The parents agree to split the kids on different nights of the week, but it's clear that the deal has nothing to do with the kids but more to do with the parents' inability to give one inch.  The boys, naturally, take sides.  Walt sides with Bernard (he has learned that Joan had a long-standing affair), while Frank sides with Joan because Bernard is such a jerk.The movie follows these characters through their misery.  Bernard is cheap and angry.  Joan is slightly successful and selfish.  Walt passes off Pink Floyd's "Hey You" as a "song I wrote" at a school talent show.  (In a therapy session, he defends his actions because he "thought he could have written it," and therefore the fact that someone had already done so is a mere technicality.)  What little Frank does to act out, besides drinking and putting cashews up his nose for long-term storage, is best left for you to discover - it's pretty unpleasasnt.The title of the movie refers to a lonely happy memory in the life of one of the boys.  Ultimately, the movie is a cautionary tale to parents everywhere that your children deny you the right to be self-absorbed jerks, because then you will teach them to be self-absorbed jerks.  Unfortunately, the very people who need to hear this message are the kind of people who will dismiss "The Squid and the Whale" as "minor Baumbach."This is far from a feel-good movie.  It's actually one of the best "feel-bad" movies I've ever seen.  I may never watch it again, but I'm glad that I got the warning Baumbach has fired off.
summary: An expertly rendered but miserable examination of pride and failure

reviewText: "Who told you that you were naked?" God asked. "Did you eat the fruit that I told you not to eat?" The man answered, "The woman you put here with me gave me the fruit, and I ate it." The Lord God asked the woman, "Why did you do this?" She replied, "The snake tricked me into eating it." Genesis 3:11-13"It's not my fault-the cry we've made every day since Cain was born. Down somewhere in the heart, there's always an awareness of just how wrong the world is, how fallen and broken and incomplete. This is the guilty knowledge, the failure of innocence, against which we snarl and fight: It's just the way things are; it's not my fault. What would genuine innocence look like, if it ever came into the world? I know the answer I am called to believe: like a child born in a cattle shed. But to understand why that is an answer, to see it clearly, we are also compelled to know our guilt for the world, to feel it all the way to the bottom." Joseph Bottom, First Things Online Blog, December 20, 2005.When things go wrong, when our world does not make sense, we tend to blame others, self-righteously denying the possibility that we are at fault, or we cower into a ball and soak in our own bile of self-pity. We witness the exacerbation of these reactions in Noah Baumbach's The Squid and the Whale. This autobiographical fiction is the story of a broken family in 1986 Brooklyn. Jeff Daniels is Bernard Berkman, the self proclaimed heir to the writing style of Kafka, who in reality is a Brooklyn College literature professor who has not been able to get a novel published in some time. Laura Linney is his wife, Joan Berkman, with a burgeoning writing career of her own that has riled the jealousy of Bernard. Jesse Eisenberg plays their 16 year old son Walt, and Owen Cline plays 12 year old Frank.Bernard and Joan announce to the boys that they are separating, and the boys will rotate every night living with mom or dad. Joan has had a series of affairs, leaving every possible hint for Bernard, save jumping in the sack with one of her beaus in front of him. There is no other way to describe Bernard than to call him what he is, a pretentious [jerk]. He blames the divorce entirely on Joan, failing to see his condescending nature as in anyway responsible for the situation. Walt gravitates toward his father, trying to emulate him and win his affection, placing the blame on his mother. Owen sees through his father, sympathizing with Joan, however is not without serious problems of his own.Normally, we categorize characters as either too arrogant or full of self pity, or, too full of [poop] or drowning in their own [poop]. Despite the despicability of his character, we can still sympathize with Bernard because, in his own way, he manages to be both. His deconstructionist dismissal of, say, Tale of Two Cities as "minor Dickens", or his categorization of Billy Baldwin's tennis instructer character Ivan (I think every movie should have at least one Baldwin in it; and I also think that Alec Baldwin should be permanent SNL host--but that is another column altogether) as a "Philistine" uninterested in "cultured" books and movies is arrogant and condescending. Yet, we can also sense self pity in his recognition that he is not adequate enough to win his wife's love. I think that is true of all of us, at times. We think of ourselves as superior to the men that the woman who rejects us goes for instead-the "why the heck is she with that schmuck?" line of thought. At the same time, we also wallow in sorrow at being not good enough, and reflect on our own flaws.Walt, in trying to emulate his father, tragically succeeds. He dumps his first love for no reason other than a desire to "do better", whatever that means. He plays off Pink Floyd's lyrics as his own in a fear of not being adequate. He even falls for the same women as his dad, Bernard's student Lili, who has moved in with him.The tragic figure in all of this, I think, is neither Bernard, Walt, nor Joan, but Frank. Divorced parents sharing parenting responsibilities in this movie appears sort of like what happens when parents decide to raise a child in both religions. He ends up with nothing. Lack of supervision plus witnessing his parents's problems leads Frank to seek refuge in alcohol and in finding new places (often in school) to experiment with himself sexually and leave the residue (yes, I am writing in euphemisms so that this does not get edited out of Amazon. I prefer direct language).If anyone comes out a hero in this film, and I use the term "hero" lightly, it is Joan. She is not the best mother, and she certainly was not the best wife. She at least is willing to admit that she has done wrong. She wants to change to be a better mother for her children. She is willing to take her part of the blame, while Bernard continues to believe "It's not my fault..."

reviewText: The squid and whale of the title is of course meant to be a metaphor, for life, but more accurately, the ongoing battle between two antagonists (men and women) who yet need each other.  But buried further in this name-dropping and allusive movie, is an almost overbearing homage to Godard's Breathless, which has its own multiple allusions, such as Rilke and Faulkner and the inability of men and women to live together in the modern world.  How does Daniels, playing a has-been literary lion and teacher Bernard Berkman, and his up and coming writer wife Joan, played by Laura Linney handle all this heavy stuff?  Pretty well, but how many viewers are going to pick up on the thumb across the mouth bit by both Daniels and Linney, which itself comes from Breathless?  Maybe that's why the squid and whale are in the film.  Kind of like a safety net for those not hip enough to be  up on their Goddard film history.  Still, Daniels and Linney are two really good actors, who should probably be considered for major awards.  But the people they play.  Jeez.  And their kids, Walt and Frank, know how to act out at Bernard and Joan's separation  - and quickly.  Masturbation in the library, alcohol abuse, and, mildly, plagiarizing Pink Floyd.  It's funny, at times, in that bittersweet we're all flawed Indie film sort of way. But by movie's end, you feel empty, like you have witnessed some sort of Indie style of child abuse.  Five stars for the acting.  Three stars for a story that leaves a bad taste in the mouth, and that refuses to be big enough to leave me sad or grieving (see Breathless for allusion via William Faulkner's Wild Palms).

reviewText: I'm not a collector of movies, but every once in a while a movie is just so good I have to own it. The Squid and the Whale made it into my very small DVD library very unexpectedly. It all started with a movie night at my last apartment. I didn't have anything in from Netflix, so Chris brings this movie out to screen. Of everyone I know, Chris's opinion of movies is probably the least heeded. He seems to find the worst films in the world and cherishes them while he doesn't like the best made, most entertaining, or otherwise brilliant movies. So I wasn't expecting much of anything but a sorry borefest like all his other films (for example, But I'm a Cheerleader, to be reviewed later on). When the film ended, Joe and Brian said, "Chris, never make me watch a movie like that again," but I was cheering.To be sure, this is not your typical film. It doesn't start like other films, the dialog isn't like other films, the cinematic style isn't like other films, and the end is definitely unlike other films. This is the story of divorce from the perspective of two young brothers whose parents are both accomplished authors living in Brooklyn. Divorce isn't entertaining, but story telling isn't about entertainment nearly as much as it is in telling a story (obviously). Noah Baumbach did a fantastic job writing the quirky characters and their eccentric language. They aren't speaking English as you or I would speak it for they come from a literary family where they speak of Jean-Luc Godard, Orson Welles, and Franz Kafka in depth, but in a way that is non sequitur to the story but makes sense to the conversation they're having.There is a lot of similarity between Baumbach's style and that of Wes Anderson, which can be credited to Anderson's producing this particular film (Baumbach also co-wrote Anderson's The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou). It is a very serious film, but it treats the subject in a way I can only describe as "real." Anderson makes films that are normal things, but they're funny things, and Baumbach has this in Squid perfectly. We aren't in a comedy, we're in life, but life is funny, life is sad, life is depressing. There are points in the film where we are laughing, and other parts where we're crying, and others where we're uncomfortable - real."Joan, let me ask you something. All that work I did at the end of our marriage, making dinners, cleaning up, being more attentive. It never was going to make a difference, was it? You were leaving no matter what...""You never made a dinner.""I made burgers that time you had pneumonia."Some movies you'll watch do put you int he depressing situation, but they usually all resolve in the Hollywood fashion. This one is much more like Little Miss Sunshine in that it has a melancholy ending. But the ending is still very strong and powerful.

reviewText: This movie was OK.  I know it was based on director, Noah Baumbach's childhood experiences, but you are still left asking WHY Baumbach would want to tell us this story of two loser parents in a world where few of us live.  What relevance would a New York yuppie couples' problems have on most of America?  Some of the problems each character deals with are so specific to the Upper Crust of society it was tough for me to relate.  I mean how many peoples' parents have BOTH published books and argue with them about writers' styles as typical conversation?Sure the movie shows us that the kids' lives of tranquility are no longer and that they must change and cope with the hand they have been dealt.  OK.  But, the main theme I took from this film is that it shows us what not only divorce, but also "bad parenting" can do to kids.  If this is not one of the director's points, then I missed the boat. "Bad parenting circa 1985" becomes very obvious from the mothers' extramarital affairs, then hits you in the face during the father-younger son ping pong games.  The acting is good; Jeff Daniels' character never seems to take responsibility for his or his kids' mistakes and you hate him for it.  He is that old guy at the bar who gawks at the 20 something year-old-girl and doesn't realize how obvious he's being.  Laura Linney is good as the mother who has to struggle to regain her kids' confidence.On another note, the use of Tangerine Dream's theme music to "Risky Business" had me guessing throughout.  Maybe unfamiliar to most, I wondered if Baumbach was trying to make a connection between Tom Cruise's Joel to the younger kid in this film.  I'm pretty sure that music only played when the kid was alone, as Joel was in Risky Business.  Both movies were about growing up quickly because of troubling circumstances.  Connection?  Probably.However, even if it was not the director's primary intention, I think you will enjoy the movie more if you take it first as a warning to how we handle our children in all circumstances, and then second as an autobiographical piece about growing up.

reviewText: The acting is fine in this film, as many reviewers have said. So enough said about that!In some ways this film reminds me of another well-acted film about a dysfunctional family, Ordinary People (1980). I think that Ordinary People is the better one, because the story gets a little deeper into the characters' heads. In The Squid and the Whale it felt like I was always looking at the surface of the characters, except for the brief scene when Walt, the older boy, talks with a counselor, and even then the surface is barely scratched. I thought it odd that the older boy met with a counselor while the younger boy did not.It didn't bother me that none of the characters were "likeable." It was easier to dislike the father than the mother, but the mother was pretty bad, too. I could easily sympathize with the kids, but even they were not likeable. Nor did the ambiguous ending bother me. It seemed clear enough that Walt was just beginning to come to grips with himself and his family, with the help of the counselor. Frank, the younger boy, seemed to be getting some non-professional help from his mom's lackadaisical boyfriend, the tennis instructor, though it wasn't clear how much help this guy could really give. What really bothered me was that I didn't get to know any of the characters.Other than entertainment value, I ask myself what a movie is giving me. This movie is a serious drama, not an entertainment. But what did it show me? What did I learn? This film had the courage, I will say, to show how kids can be affected by what is going on around them. There were some graphic scenes - some would say disturbing - of the younger boy "acting out." But again it just didn't go deeper than that. To those offended by these scenes, may I point out that there are plenty of horror movies about kids that kill and hardly anyone complains about those! At least this movie has the redeeming quality of showing us real life, and I give it credit for that.

Perhaps the best aspect of the entire film is that Daniels' character, Bernard Berkman, is almost cartoonish in his intellectualism and professional pride.  The only really funny bits of the movie come as Bernard denigrates the work of other writers or discusses, in dismissive fashion, the artistic or cultural tastes of others.  He is a first-class literary snob.  His performance alone, and the few chuckles it generates, are enough to save the movie.But, the movie is essentially about the misery of four rather depraved people.  Dark humor and comedy have their place, but listening to adolescents and parents curse at each other and talk openly about their (broken) sex lives will be too much for many moviegoers to take.  Don't watch this movie unless you want to find out how not to create a healthy, happy family life.

reviewText: This movie reminded me of The Royal Tennenbaums with its family of too-sophisticated-for-their-own-good intellectuals and their bad habits. Only where the Royal Tennanbaums is a comic fairytale, this movie has some harsh things to say about the elitist types that find The New Yorker and Harpers the height of creativity.Jeff Daniels and Laura Linney anchor this movie as the divorced parents. Laura Linney has a quiet resolve to survive no matter what her husband pulls, while Jeff Daniels is a bully that would never admit to the complicity in his life. He buys his son a desk that's for the wrong hand. He dismisses most writers as hacks or most of their work as minor. He repeats himself as if he's hit upon the greatest wisdom with his cliches. Yet you can see why his son sides with him throughout the movie.The movie mostly belongs to the oldest son, who sets out to be a copy of Jeff Daniels character and slowly realizes that he's a jerk. The scenes where he's repeating his father's dismissal of writers are painful because you know that he's just parroting his father, so when his girlfriend points out that the Metamorphasis is Kafka-esque because Kafka wrote it, he's got nothing else to say about the story. His greatest accomplishment is to play a Pink Floyd song at a talent show and pass it off as his own (the one false note is the talent show committee only catching on after they give him the prize money and asking for it back. I can see why the parents are clueless about 70s rock music, but I'd think that someone else would catch on especially since it's a song from The Wall). And only when he goes to mandatory therapy does he begin to understand that his mother was the only parent that actually acted like a parent.This is a great movie full of original and disturbing characters (I haven't mentioned Owen Kline's turn as a nasty 12-year old who drinks and swears throughout the movie. reviewText: THE SQUID AND THE WHALE tells a simple story. Two people who were once in love separate and the children involved have to navigate the waters of a disrupted family life. It's been done before, and it will be done again, yet I have a feeling it will not be done quite the way it is done in this film. The film focuses on Bernard Beckman, played by Jeff Daniels, who is a once great writer reduced to teaching creative writing to students who are convinced of his greatness but have no idea it is a facade. His son Walt, played by Jesse Eisenberg, believes in his father's greatness and takes his side in the divorce. Much of the humor of the film is based on Bernard's pompous personality and young Walt imitating the father he finds to be so great. Joan, Bernard's wife, played by Laura Linney is the one who is having the extramarital affairs and we believe she is trapped in her marriage, but we also see she's ready to break away. Her writing career is excelling while Bernard's is declining, and Walt resents his mother on many levels, again because he's blinded by his conceptions of his father. The youngest son Frank, played by Owen Kline adds some comic relief and in some ways, it is through his actions we see how deeply pained Walt and Frank are by the divorce.The dialogue in this film is outstanding, and the acting is superb. Jeff Daniels is convincing as the once brilliant lout, and Jesse Eisenberg will have a career to watch. The conflicts raised in the film are not resolved, or at least not in the usual sense, but in a way this gives the film a realistic edge. My guess is that this film will become better known when Golden Globe and Academy Award nominations are announced. For now it will play to film lovers who will find it entertaining, but like so many wonderful films, it will take a nomination or two for it to be noticed.
summary: A Film That Shows A Different Side Of Life

reviewText: "The Squid and the Whale" is a small film which critics would unanimously praise, but not all general viewers would fall in love with. I happened to find it interesting and even touching, but it also features a set of characters, well-drawn and well-acted, but not the kind of people you can instantly identify with, including a boy who is seen drinking beer or masturbating in the library (played by Kevin Kline's real-life son Owen). Some things might be off-putting, but the film's insightful observations about people are genuine and delicately shown.`The Squid and the Whale" is about the divorcing parents Mr. and Mrs. Berkman and their two young boys Walt and Frank (Jesse Eisenberg and Owen Kline) who have to deal with the new life. Jeff Daniels effectively plays Bernard Berkman, a pompous writer and father who still loves his family in his own way. That's what he thinks, but unfortunately for him, his wife Joan (Laura Linney) does not share the same values any more, and one day they decide to separate.The whole process before and after the divorce, and the two boys' reactions to it are both depicted with downbeat humor mixed with references to classic literature and pop culture. But these references are not there as in-jokes, but to show the characters' personalities. The name of "New Yorker" is impressive enough for the father who habitually uses his literary knowledge as weapon to dismiss others (including his wife and her books) as second-rate or `Philistine.' The elder brother Walt uses the same tactics, following the advice from his daddy, only to find later ... much too late ... the shallowness behind these words.By the time the two boys (and we) come to know the true reasons for the divorce and joint custody, we realize that the film is realistic and convincing in details describing the human nature seen in someone very close to us without making us too conscious of the narrative skills and clever script. But the descriptions are all done compassionately without any patronizing tone. Parents and brothers are not perfect humans, which is no news at all, but rarely expressed as subtly as this small film.
summary: Convincing and Compelling Portrait of Family Members That Is More Poignant Than Funny

reviewText: Completely overlooked at the Oscars, "The Squid and the Whale" features two of the strongest performances of 2005 from Jeff Daniels and Laura Linney and a powerful script. How this gem of a drama got overlooked (and why Daniels, Linney and Baumbach weren't nominated for awards is beyond me). Joan (Laura Linney) and Bernard (Jeff Daniels) are in the middle of a nasty divorce that's pulling apart the lives of their two sons Walt (Jesse) and Frank (Owen Kline). Bernard is a self important "writer" whose career and marriage have gone astray. He blames everyone but himself and when his wife's writing career takes off it complicates things even further making the bitterness a canyon vs. a river between them. It's clear that we have a dynsfunctional family here--one of the kids masturbates and wipes the result on items in the house as a form of revenge. Clearly this film isn't for everyone and will revolt some people. There aren't any pivotal plot points that drive the story-it's more a series of events, much like life, strung together with the emotional turmoil of the story driving the story forward. It's a riveting film but may not be for everyone.A sharp extremely good transfer is a major highlight for this film. Colors are muted but accurate and keep in mind this isn't supposed to be an eye popping film like "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory". The 5.1 sound has the quality one would expect from a new movie but keep in mind that the audio is designed for a drama not a big action film. Atmospheric effects are nicely placed around the speakers.Noah Baumbach provides an intelligent observant commentary track full of trivia about the shooting of the movie and the performances in the film. The behind-the-scenes featurette is pretty good as well with some thoughtful comments from the actors. The "conversation" with Baumbach and film critic Philip Lopate is probably the more interesting of the two shorts included with Baumbach discussing everything from the inspiration for the film to why the film ends the way it does.A terrific, emotional powerful film that touches on the victims of divorce, "The Squid and the Whale" probably had the worst title of any of the films that came out last year which may have impacted its performance with audiences. The actors give terrific performances and it's a shame that the Academy Awards chose to overlook these performances.

reviewText: Moviegoers who attend films for plot arcs and resolution will find The Squid and the Whale to be this year's Lost in Translation, the film loved by critics (and peoples who want to be critics) but hated by the mainstream; many of the latter group will walk from theaters saying to themselves, "OK, what was that?"No earth-shattering plots exist; no great stories are told. The 80 minute film is simply about the aftermath of a divorce on a family...a very unique family in some ways, but not unlike any family in others.The Mother and Father (Linney and Daniels) both hold PHDs in Literature, and their sons display the signs of being reared by scholars. They are sensitive and analytical, both disastrous traits for children dealing with divorce. Those qualities also ripen the young characters, especially the older son who fumbles his way through trying to sound like his favorite literary authority (his father). He's still learning, however, and often times the way he name-drops writers and terms works to expose his amateurish understanding of his subject matter (like when he refers to a work by Franz Kafka as "Kafka-esque").As the boys and their parents have difficulties dealing with the aftermath of the divorce, the film's conflicts go into uncomfortable areas. The lady taking tickets at the theater I attended warned an inquisitive patron that "it gets ugly".Indeed, it does.But the ugly, unsweetened depiction of the consequences of divorce on the contemporary American family seems to be the film's thesis. For many, that will not be enough to justify a viewing. The Squid and the Whale seems to anticipate such criticism and makes a pre-emptive strike against would-be detractors, calling people who do not appreciate interesting films "Philistines". That may be a bit harsh, but at least the film understands its place.

reviewText: I was rather disappointed to see Laura Linney in The Exorcism of Emily Rose, because it's not her kind of movies. She's most suitable to play real characters in indie films like her signature work in You Can Count On Me. It's clear that Linney has once again returned to her Indie roots by starring in The Squid and the Whale, and she truly delivered another Oscar-caliber performance. This film features probably Jeff Daniel's career-best performance, and he had a great deal of chemistry working opposite Linney and the young actors. This film could easily be made into a sad drama, but the director aimed for a comedy instead. It's a great film about the impact on a family post divorce. Honestly, I was so surprised that this film had made me laugh out loud so many times and even the saddest moments didn't move me to tears.Laura Linney plays Joan, a highly educated housewife to Bernard(Daniel) who used to be a successful writer, but reduced to literature teacher. Joan had secretly been having an affair and she had became incompatible with Bernard two years prior to their divorce that shocked their two sons(Jesse Einsberg and Owen Klein). She's also becoming an acclaimed writer when she's gets her own book published, so it instantly caused Bernard to be very jealous. They shared custody of the two boys, and it's clear that Walt(Einsberg) has a stronger bond with Bernard, while the younger son Frank is closed to Mommy. Things really fall apart in their lives as a result of the divorce. Joan started dating the local tennis pro played by William Baldwin, while Bernard hit it off with his student Lili(Anna Paquin, who was Jeff Daniel's daughter in Fly Away Home like ten years ago!) Walt becomes a liar and heartbreaker, while Frank abuses alcohol, curses at things and people, and masterbates compulsively. Oh, there's the cat in the house that also becomes an issue....This film successfully achieves the look of the '80s and the ragged cinematography works perfectly for it's mood. The dialogue is interlectually stimulating, and the cast is just perfect. I do hope Linney and Daniel will get some acting nominations, and I was very impressed by Owen Wilson's performance.
